Out of all the DMC games, I've enjoyed this game's first playthrough the most.
Out of all the playable DMC characters, I've enjoyed this game's Vergil the most.
Out of all the DMC boss fights, I've enjoyed this game's final fights the most.

However, there's a lot to complain about too.
 - The main cast characters play very differently and you'll dislike at least one of them.
 - Hell Judeccas are the worst DMC enemy ever, and they're in almost every mission on higher difficulties.
 - The lock-on system almost always picks the enemy that you want to lock-on the least.
 - Dante's battle theme doesn't do him justice.
 - Platforming, camera issues, controller disconnects, loading screens, blah blah.

If you haven't played any other of the DMC games, you'll be fine. This one's on the easier side for sure.
Unless you're looking for a 100% experience. That boils down to S-ranking all missions on all difficulties with the main cast (can't do it on Vergil, which is a huge shame) - this S rank grind is very tough and extremely demanding at times. But it's not boring; gotta give it that much.

Most of my hours are on console, got the game on PC to test out multiplayer mods, but either way I can't recommend this game enough (on controller! This game is designed for controller, a lot of stuff just feels wrong or is uncomfortable on keyboard). The story feels like a mostly natural continuation of the previous game (given that it was ten years after the initial release of DMC 4), while the gameplay is a large step up. If you've played any DMC games, it's likely you've played this one, but if you've been holding out, it's my pick for best game in the series. I understand there's a lot of contention for that title when it comes to DMC, however, it evolves the changes made in DMC 4 for the better, there's more variety in gameplay with there being 3 playable characters in the base game, all who have entirely different playstyles from each other, and it removes the issue of level design that DMC 4 had, with each level being specifically meant for one character, even the ones that you play as multiple have different variations for that character. There are more weapons to use on Dante (including both guns and devil arms there's 8 (going off the 'finished" version of each weapon without the parts), the gauntlet type weapon that's appeared in every game that's not DMC 2 has changed completely and for the better, I'd always thought the charge mechanic didn't work for the pace of DMC, and the unique charge/level sort of thing Balrog does is way more manageable for the pace of fights, you can swap styles again, with some extra improvements from DMC 4, and you use red orbs to upgrade everything again, meaning they have an actual use for serious play (even if they really just become a number once you have everything). 

Nero's changed a lot too, while his gun and sword stay mostly the same, his demon arm gimmick has been almost completely changed, you still have the enemy grappling hook think going on, but there are a ton of new 'Devil Breakers', which each give their own sort of playstyle to Nero, while also being best utilized by swapping fluidly between them with their high damaging finishers in the 'breakage' attacks, though sticking to one in specific arm isn't something that's punished if you want to keep your favorite through a level (though the damage will almost certainly be missed on bosses).

V is something completely new to the series, he's a sort of summoner, relying on familiars (which happen be bosses from DMC 1) to deal damage for him, and even act as his dodges, while he has to finish enemies off himself, meaning he isn't completely risk free. I've had plenty of fun playing V, however, he's certainly a bit of a snag in the flow of the gameplay, he's not nearly as satisfying as Dante or Nero as it feels like YOU aren't doing the combos, and he deals a bit less damage than the other two, making fights drag on against tougher enemies, especially on higher difficulties, and his bosses aren't particularly enjoyable given just how little control you really have over your damage if you spend a lot of time dodging the way I do, however it's a unique playstyle I'm glad they touched on, even if it's not something I'd want to see return.

All in all, I spoke a little too much about the specifics because I'm super passionate about this game. It's my game of 2019, and it's seriously worth a try if you like ANY character action game, be it Metal Gear Rising, Bayonetta, or whatever else.

Cathartic story, great graphics and optimization, the best Dante gameplay of the series (also, I'm in the team that enjoys V). And in the name of Sparda, they went full bananas on the soundtrack. The dynamic combat tracks synching to rank actually fill you with [b]motivation[/b] to get good.

The only downside, which is a great one, is no playable Lady & Trish DLC. They were super fun to play in 4 ([spoiler] and with the ending cutscene, you'd think they had planned to release one. Come on, Capcom, you're even selling a DLC to modify their outfits but they're NOT playable? [/spoiler]) I suppose Capcom never wants to release a perfect DMC game... but damn, it went really close with DMC5.

you don't come to DMC for masterclass storytelling. you come here to Kick Demons 365 ways from Sunday. the snarky comments, the soundtrack, the weapons and playstyles that feel varied and fully realized next to some well needed updates to mechanics of the past (Dante's switching & Nero's Exceed for instance), getting higher grades than what teachers gave in school, and just the full on fun to be seen and played in the game.

the story itself is actually pretty good, it's continuing the story of 4 with Nero, with plenty of callbacks to 1 & 3, both major and minor, and a conclusion that feels pretty satisfying for people who love Dante & Vergil next to giving Nero alot more time to come into his own. lots of the reveals are going to be expected IMO, but expected in a good way.

it even has a recap story in case you're new and have never played a DMC game before or need a refresher.

one criticism i do have is the "multiplayer". or rather, lack there of. yeah, if you're expecting to play with 1-2 other people in game, you'll be disappointed, it might as well not even be there to begin with. i would like to see a future DMC title if possible go more for Co-op encouragment, but for this it's basically just a single player game. which...honestly is just fine, considering how many games are live service and basically enforce you to play with others constantly nowadays.

overall, DMC 5 is such a great time sink, plenty of fun to be had, Live Action Cutscenes available to grab and use for key moments in every level, and a difficulty curve that feels satisfying the more you learn and get used to playing as characters.

I've gotten into Devil May Cry Series after I saw the Netflix Adaptation. After playing this game and learning about the entire lore of Devil May Cry, the games put the Adaptation to shame. After knowing about Capcom for a long time (lots of exposure to Megaman Series), since it was a Capcom game, I decided to try it. BEST GAME EVER. As of now I'm still trying to 100% the game, after which I will focus on Vergil's campaign, and try to master him too. The entire experience was beautiful, with the best Soundtracks ever, best action, combos, gameplay as a whole is an unforgettable experience. Some funny bits here and there, which do not fell forced at all (Nero and Nico's dialogues, Dante himself etc). Amazing story as well. There are some things that I did not like (Dante's Soundtrack, V's Campaign, Mission 10 and 8 being annoyingly hard to S rank, even in SOS, Bloody Palace 97) but they barely bring the experience down, as the rest of the game with blast your ears and eyes with MOTIVATION. The game reaches its peak after Mission 14, so Mission 15-20 are my favorite to revisit. *MAYBE* in the future I will try the DMC Collection and DMC4, but I am having so much fun with the 5(?)th entry ("?" because DMC Reboot is technically the 5th game, but canonically this is the 5th game) of the series that I don't think I will play the others. If you are looking for a fighting 3d game with combos, look no further, Devil May Cry 5 is the game for you.

As someone who grew up playing the original DMC titles back in the PS2 days, this game feels like a love letter from Capcom to the series' fans. It's somewhat of an amalgamation of everything that made 1 and 3 great with a few new twists and new mechanics here and there. It feels extremely satisfying to play and is absolutely gorgeous to look at. I gotta say this game boasts some of the best cutscene direction I've ever seen in any game ever too. The choreography and cinematography are spectacular, and the writing is genuinely laugh out loud funny at times.

It does feel more straightforward compared to the previous titles, though that's just me being nitpicky because I really enjoyed the puzzles and exploration from the first few titles. You can't really expect that level of exploration from a mainstream AAA game released in 2019 though, so it's more of a modern game design quirk than anything else and again, just a minor nitpick.

The only real downside is just how short the first playthrough is, especially for a major release that happens to be very pricey in my region. I completed my first playthrough in 10 hours. That's...not what I expected. At all. It feels as though that just when the game and story are starting to get really good, it ends abruptly and you're presented with a credits screen. You are treated to a lot of additional content once you beat the game though, but still...10 hours for a first playthrough is very disappointing.

All in all, this is a very solid entry in the series. Despite how short the campaign is, I'd recommend it to anyone who either grew up playing these games and newcomers alike. It's a lot of fun.

This game has astonishing visuals and a good reputation so I gave it a try, but good god it's a terrible play experience for me and I really just didn't enjoy it, and once enemy health bars got a bit longer I couldn't bare to continue playing.
There're several issues with this game that makes it unfun for me:
1) janky controls: 
This game's attack tracking is extremely awkward, because locking-on to enemies isn't actually something to help you see and target, but actually a "mode/stance‚Äú switch used to allow various combat moves to be performed. I don't know why any modern game should do this, instead of actually implementing a stance system.
2) defense feels strange:
The characters you can play as are all extremely mobile on the offense, capable of dashing across half the screen in one move, but there's not really a lot of good defensive options. There's rolling, technically, but its range is incredible small and its movement is slow, and it can only be triggered in the "locked on" stance/mode and requires pressing 3 keys simultaneously to be performed (lock-on, direction, and the jump key) and it's just incredibly annoying that this is how the game wants to handle roll. If you played other action games (fromsoft ones, witcher 3, gow...) the muscle memory just makes it unbearable here.
You can also jump to evade attacks but it just feels very awkward to me because the amount of horizontal change is limited and thus the game's camera makes it difficult to eyeball how much vertical displacement is needed to jump over an attack rather than be caught in it.
3) spongy enemy:
the game isn't that hard in terms of "you will die 50+ times" but it's a bit grindy and gets boring quickly in the Dynasty Warriors sense because there're a lot of enemies that cannot put up a fight against you and can be stun locked endlessly, but these same enemies require you to keep slashing them for a few dozen strikes before they die, and it's just a waste of time in my personal experience. There's not really any challenge other than trying to look stylish, but how stylish is it when the enemy is just a piece of meat you can juggle endlessly without resistance? 
so the game kinda just swings between "beat-em-up 3d with air combos" and "bosses immune to juggles that you have to jump over rather than dodge" and it's just a very unintuitive way to play, and then the janky controls just push it beyond my range of enjoyment.
I really like the vibe, the stylishness, the music, the characters, the tone... I just don't like this game's game part. If even just one of my main complaints was avoided, such as:
1) a bit more modern and intuitive control, and less attacks that require timings so precise that plenty of guides feature failed takes ("opps, even I the guide maker can't reliably perform this acion when filming in 
the training room, guess it must be fun to try to perform it while doing a dozen other things in game huh?"
2) a typical defense system (parry, block, and/or dodge, I prefer dodge but will accept parry and block systems) rather than this weird jumping situation
3) less spongy enemies that you can obviously beat no problem but nevertheless requires you to combo them for half a minute before they die
Not a good experience for me. The game just feels to stiff with the move set and the characters are not very interesting.

DMC 5 has a lot to like, but I cannot call this a good game.

First, the positives.
Amazing music.
Superb high-production cutscenes.
Amazing optimisation, my PC is below the recommended requirements, yet on the maximum graphics it ran super smoothly, not once did it lag or stutter.
The combat is great even if awkward. The variety of weapons, skills and moves is stellar. They finally fixed the issue I had with 3rd and 4th game that Dante can only use one style at a time, well now you can use all styles at the same time! And there are many different characters and they all have distinct skills, moves and weapons. And all are fun to play. The only issue though, which is a major issue is that enemes can get away so fast and you move so slow... There are skills where you can dash to the enemy fast if they are close, but other than that I wish that you ran way faster during the combat.

Now, as for the negatives. The game shares a lot of identical skills from DMC 4 and you have to rebuy/relearn them all over again... It's lazy. At least, they could've tried giving some plot-related reason like in Deus Ex Mankind Divided why you have to relearn all those same skills all over again.

The auto-mode can perform some moves well, but it also blocks you from using half the styles and numerous moves and skills the very least, so avoid using it, unless you're fine to be stuck with just a few moves. I can't understand how come DMC 1 had such a fantastic auto-mode which did wonders, yet all the later games have this mixbag of an auto-mode.

Also, what the hell is this CO-OP attempt? Yes, attempt. It randomly connects random people to my game or vice-versa, and most of the levels we do not even meet as we're in separate areas, but we may meet in one or two rooms, but only if we played at the same pace and reached that place at the same time... What kind of crap is this? To think of it, it's such a wasted opportunity... They could've made an actual proper CO-OP in this game since you already have numerous different playable characters with different skillsets and it's already possible to play with other players... What a waste!

The biggest issue I have with this game which is a deal breaker for me is that the majority of the levels are so bland and uninspired. The first few levels are in the city and they are highly varied, then almost all of the rest of the levels are in this single setting of purple void world. They have simple designs and just feature the same environments over and over and over again. This is a massive lack of variety and I simply cannot imagine myself ever replaying this game, especially since I found most of the levels too repetitive and dull the first time already. There is even that one boss rush level where you fight the same bosses again... This is becoming a trend in DMC games and it is mega lazy. Even a good combat is not enough to save it.

Overall, it is an okay game, a lot better than DMC 4, but it had the potential to be way better than what it is.

I think the review section of this game is an echo chamber of people who love it for some reason and this might make you think that this is generally a good game, which I think it isn't.
I'll start with the positives: the combat is really good. The way you can chain combos and different attack types is amazing. 
Now, to the negatives:
- the environments are extremely bland. If you go ask chatgpt to generate you a list of example scifi fantasy settings it'd probably cover half the game locations.
- dialogues are extremely cheesy, uninteresting and cliche.
- the easy game mode is too easy, the hard is too hard.
- the upgrade system is nothing phenomenal. Japanese game developers have been pulling the same tricks since 30 years,
- you play different characters during the course of the game and it is evident that some are better designed than others, ofc this quickly feels uninspiring, since you never really attach to your character,
- the missions are mostly linear, no new mechanics exist that make them different from the hundreds of action games that you might have already played.

To put it shortly, this is a MID game at BEST. If this is, according to many, the best DMC game, then I doubt that the DMC series was ever good to begin with.

They finally fixed the issue I had with 3rd and 4th game that Dante can only use one style at a time, well now you can use all styles at the same time! And there are many different characters and they all have distinct skills, moves and weapons. And all are fun to play. The only issue though, which is a major issue is that enemes can get away so fast and you move so slow... There are skills where you can dash to the enemy fast if they are close, but other than that I wish that you ran way faster during the combat.

Now, as for the negatives. The game shares a lot of identical skills from DMC 4 and you have to rebuy/relearn them all over again... It's lazy. At least, they could've tried giving some plot-related reason like in Deus Ex Mankind Divided why you have to relearn all those same skills all over again.

The auto-mode can perform some moves well, but it also blocks you from using half the styles and numerous moves and skills the very least, so avoid using it, unless you're fine to be stuck with just a few moves. I can't understand how come DMC 1 had such a fantastic auto-mode which did wonders, yet all the later games have this mixbag of an auto-mode.

Also, what the hell is this CO-OP attempt? Yes, attempt. It randomly connects random people to my game or vice-versa, and most of the levels we do not even meet as we're in separate areas, but we may meet in one or two rooms, but only if we played at the same pace and reached that place at the same time... What kind of crap is this? To think of it, it's such a wasted opportunity... They could've made an actual proper CO-OP in this game since you already have numerous different playable characters with different skillsets and it's already possible to play with other players... What a waste!

The biggest issue I have with this game which is a deal breaker for me is that the majority of the levels are so bland and uninspired. The first few levels are in the city and they are highly varied, then almost all of the rest of the levels are in this single setting of purple void world. They have simple designs and just feature the same environments over and over and over again. This is a massive lack of variety and I simply cannot imagine myself ever replaying this game, especially since I found most of the levels too repetitive and dull the first time already. There is even that one boss rush level where you fight the same bosses again... This is becoming a trend in DMC games and it is mega lazy. Even a good combat is not enough to save it.

Overall, it is an okay game, a lot better than DMC 4, but it had the potential to be way better than what it is.


6/10

I love Devil May Cry, and the visuals for this game look very pretty. It's also amazing how they face scan real people for the character models, so it truly feels like a movie. Soundtrack is amazing, orbs and gold orbs are much easier to obtain this time around, However, this game gets a no from me.

The story is very boring and doesn't get interesting 'til the very end. The areas are very linear, and you're just going from one area straight forward to the next without much thought. You also cannot go back if you missed something. The combat can feel very smooth, then at times, it can also feel oddly clunky.

The Playable Vergil DLC is whatever, you're just retracing the story mode Nero's steps as Vergil. He has 3 weapons, one of them being the Mirage Edge which just plays identical to Dante's sword, which is pretty lazy.

I would also like to add that the story just feels like rushed fan service for long time players through references of DMC 1 to 4, and basically a "sorry we've been gone so long" since DMC4 released in 2008. Like okay, here's Nero from DMC4, the story continues with him, then 9 chapters later, Dante finally shows up, and you're already fighting Vergil a couple chapters later. If you're a long time fan and curious on how the story continues, it's a must buy. If you're new/curious to the series, you're better off playing older titles from the HD Collection.

This game has astonishing visuals and a good reputation so I gave it a try, but good god it's a terrible play experience for me and I really just didn't enjoy it, and once enemy health bars got a bit longer I couldn't bare to continue playing.
There're several issues with this game that makes it unfun for me:
1) janky controls: 
This game's attack tracking is extremely awkward, because locking-on to enemies isn't actually something to help you see and target, but actually a "mode/stance‚Äú switch used to allow various combat moves to be performed. I don't know why any modern game should do this, instead of actually implementing a stance system.
2) defense feels strange:
The characters you can play as are all extremely mobile on the offense, capable of dashing across half the screen in one move, but there's not really a lot of good defensive options. There's rolling, technically, but its range is incredible small and its movement is slow, and it can only be triggered in the "locked on" stance/mode and requires pressing 3 keys simultaneously to be performed (lock-on, direction, and the jump key) and it's just incredibly annoying that this is how the game wants to handle roll. If you played other action games (fromsoft ones, witcher 3, gow...) the muscle memory just makes it unbearable here.
You can also jump to evade attacks but it just feels very awkward to me because the amount of horizontal change is limited and thus the game's camera makes it difficult to eyeball how much vertical displacement is needed to jump over an attack rather than be caught in it.
3) spongy enemy:
the game isn't that hard in terms of "you will die 50+ times" but it's a bit grindy and gets boring quickly in the Dynasty Warriors sense because there're a lot of enemies that cannot put up a fight against you and can be stun locked endlessly, but these same enemies require you to keep slashing them for a few dozen strikes before they die, and it's just a waste of time in my personal experience. There's not really any challenge other than trying to look stylish, but how stylish is it when the enemy is just a piece of meat you can juggle endlessly without resistance? 
so the game kinda just swings between "beat-em-up 3d with air combos" and "bosses immune to juggles that you have to jump over rather than dodge" and it's just a very unintuitive way to play, and then the janky controls just push it beyond my range of enjoyment.
I really like the vibe, the stylishness, the music, the characters, the tone... I just don't like this game's game part. If even just one of my main complaints was avoided, such as:
1) a bit more modern and intuitive control, and less attacks that require timings so precise that plenty of guides feature failed takes ("opps, even I the guide maker can't reliably perform this acion when filming in 
the training room, guess it must be fun to try to perform it while doing a dozen other things in game huh?"
2) a typical defense system (parry, block, and/or dodge, I prefer dodge but will accept parry and block systems) rather than this weird jumping situation
3) less spongy enemies that you can obviously beat no problem but nevertheless requires you to combo them for half a minute before they die
I had my brightness to brightest but for some reason the screen was still very dark... Don't recommend it.
